risks.title: Expired and Expiring Quality Certifications
risks.description: The supplier's ISO 9001:2015 certification for the Hamburg site expired on 2024-09-14, prior to this analysis. Furthermore, the critical IATF 16949 certification for the same site is set to expire on 2024-11-30. The Novaterra site's IATF 16949 certificate also expires in Nov 2025. Operating with expired or soon-to-expire certifications poses a significant quality and compliance risk across all brands, as it may indicate a lapse in the supplier's quality management system.
risks.impact: Potential for production halts if certifications are not renewed, inability to supply to brands requiring valid certifications, and risk of systemic quality degradation. This could lead to major project delays and recalls.
risks.mitigation: Immediately request and verify the renewed ISO 9001 certificate and the renewal plan for the IATF 16949 certificate. Make contract signing conditional upon receipt of valid certifications. Implement a quarterly certification status review process with the supplier for all their relevant manufacturing and development sites.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Demand immediate submission of the renewed ISO 9001 certificate for the Hamburg site.
Action 2: Require a documented and time-bound action plan for the IATF 16949 renewal for the Hamburg and Novaterra sites.
Action 3: Add a clause in the supply agreement requiring the supplier to maintain all necessary certifications and provide 90-day advance notice of any changes to certification status.

risks.title: Significant Technical Non-Compliance and Deviations
risks.description: The supplier has declared non-compliance on 24 requirements for the Clutch System DCS2-X. Key deviations include: proposing a lower safety factor for bottoming torque (Req 2.2.1), guaranteeing operational life only for specific European mission profiles (Req 2.8.1), failing durability test standards (Req 2.13.7), and being unable to commit to vehicle-level noise emission standards (Req 2.10.7). These deviations indicate a potential mismatch between the supplier's standard product and the customer group's global platform requirements.
risks.impact: Risk of premature component failure, increased warranty claims, and failure to meet regulatory requirements in specific markets (e.g., noise regulations). This could lead to costly redesigns, validation failures, and damage to brand reputation.
risks.mitigation: Mandate a point-by-point technical review meeting to address all 24 non-compliances. For each deviation, require the supplier to provide a detailed risk assessment and a proposal to meet the requirement, including any cost or timing implications. Do not proceed with sourcing until a mutually agreed-upon and documented resolution for all critical non-compliances is achieved.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Schedule a mandatory technical deep-dive workshop with supplier's engineering leads.
Action 2: For each non-compliance, formally document the accepted deviation, the mitigation plan, or the supplier's commitment to comply.
Action 3: Update the Design Verification Plan (DVP) to include specific tests validating the resolutions for previously non-compliant items.

risks.title: Dismissive Stance on Functional Safety (ISO 26262)
risks.description: The supplier has dismissed multiple checklist items related to functional safety (ISO 26262) as 'Not relevant'. This includes questions about safety analyses, hazard assessments, and safety-integrated development processes. This contradicts the customer's clear interest in functional safety and indicates a potential cultural and process gap. The supplier's self-assessment that the component is 'not safety-critical' may not align with the customer group's vehicle-level safety case.
risks.impact: Significant legal and liability exposure in case of a field failure, even if the component is not traditionally 'safety-critical'. Inability to meet the customer group's internal safety engineering standards, potentially blocking use of the part in future platforms. This could lead to project cancellation or major legal disputes.
risks.mitigation: Immediately schedule a meeting with the supplier's quality and engineering leadership to clarify the customer group's functional safety requirements. A formal, joint assessment must be conducted to determine the applicable Automotive Safety Integrity Level (ASIL) for the component. The supplier must commit to providing the required safety documentation (e.g., safety plan, FMEA) as a contractual obligation.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Formally communicate the customer group's policy on functional safety and ISO 26262 applicability.
Action 2: Conduct a joint Hazard Analysis and Risk Assessment (HARA) to align on the component's safety goals.
Action 3: Make the delivery of a compliant Safety Case a key milestone in the project plan and a condition for final payment.

risks.title: High-Risk Shared Production Capacity and Bottlenecks
risks.description: The supplier's capacity for key components is shared across the entire customer group (Germanic Auto, Norse Trucks, American Hauler) and at least one other external OEM. The quoted peak annual volumes (e.g., 126,000 units for 4288-792) are precariously close to the calculated nominal annual capacity (130,000 units), leaving minimal buffer for demand spikes. Identified bottlenecks in 'Assembly Process' and 'CNC Machining' further exacerbate this risk.
risks.impact: Inability to meet concurrent peak demand from multiple brands within the customer group, leading to line-down situations, production delays, and strained relationships. The supplier may be forced to prioritize one customer over another.
risks.mitigation: Conduct an on-site capacity audit (Run@Rate) at the Lyon facility to validate the stated OEE and technical capacity figures. Contractually obligate the supplier to a specific, ring-fenced capacity for the customer group. Request the 'Axion Automotive Lyon Capacity Analysis 2025 Q3' presentation and secure commitments for the planned expansion.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Secure and review the supplier's capacity expansion plan presentation.
Action 2: Define and contractually agree upon dedicated capacity allocation for the customer group.
Action 3: Establish a quarterly capacity review process to monitor utilization and proactively address potential shortfalls.

risks.title: Excessively Long and Vague Supply Lead Times
risks.description: The supplier states a standard delivery lead time of 95 working days (approx. 19 weeks) and an escalation lead time of 70 working days (approx. 14 weeks). These times are exceptionally long for the automotive industry and are vaguely attributed to 'raw material procurement times'. This indicates a significant vulnerability in their upstream supply chain and a lack of agility.
risks.impact: Reduced operational flexibility for all brands, forcing the customer group to hold higher safety stock, which increases inventory costs. Inability to react to market demand changes or recover quickly from a supply disruption.
risks.mitigation: Require the supplier to provide a detailed breakdown of the lead time components (procurement, manufacturing, transit). Establish a joint task force to identify and mitigate the root causes of the long raw material lead times. Contractually agree on a lead time reduction roadmap with clear targets and timelines.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Request a detailed value stream map of the end-to-end supply chain, including sub-suppliers.
Action 2: Negotiate a contractual agreement for the supplier to hold a certain level of raw material or semi-finished goods inventory.
Action 3: Explore options for regional sourcing of raw materials to reduce dependency on a single long-lead-time source.

risks.title: Pending Compliance on Substance Prohibitions
risks.description: For Norse Trucks, compliance with 'Substance prohibitions and restrictions' (Req 3.4.3) is marked as 'Pending' and to be finalized during development. With differing regional regulations like EU REACh, this ambiguity poses a compliance risk. A late discovery of a prohibited substance could affect all brands if the component is used on a global platform.
risks.impact: Risk of production halts, forced redesigns, and inability to sell vehicles in key markets (e.g., EU) if the final component contains restricted substances. This could lead to significant rework costs and delays.
risks.mitigation: Mandate that the supplier provides a preliminary Bill of Materials (BOM) and substance declaration (e.g., via IMDS) before contract signing. Final compliance must be a mandatory, non-negotiable gate for the 'Design Freeze' milestone, with penalties for failure to comply.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Require a preliminary substance compliance statement against all target market regulations (EU, US, South America).
Action 2: Make full material data disclosure in the IMDS system a condition for PPAP approval.
Action 3: Incorporate a specific warranty clause covering compliance with all relevant substance regulations.

risks.title: Direct Competition in the Independent Aftermarket (IAM)
risks.description: The supplier has explicitly stated they will not grant exclusive rights for spare parts (Req C-1) and will compete 'Partly' in the Independent Aftermarket (IAM) (Req C-2). This will directly erode the customer group's high-margin aftermarket business for this component across all brands.
risks.impact: Loss of profitable aftermarket revenue and margin for the customer group. Brand erosion if the supplier's IAM parts are cheaper and of comparable quality. Difficulty in managing the lifecycle pricing of the spare part.
risks.mitigation: Negotiate specific terms to manage aftermarket competition. Options include: a time-based embargo before the supplier can enter the IAM, a commitment to not use the customer's branding on IAM parts, or a revenue-sharing agreement for IAM sales. The incomplete spare parts concept (Req A-1) must also be delivered and agreed upon.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Negotiate and contractually define the terms of the supplier's entry into the IAM (e.g., 3-year delay post-SOP).
Action 2: Require the submission of a complete spare parts concept (ETK) before contract finalization.
Action 3: Define distinct branding and part numbering requirements for OES (Original Equipment Spares) vs. IAM parts.

risks.title: Dependency on Outsourced Critical Processes
risks.description: The supplier outsources critical processes, including 'tool production', 'surface coating', and 'heat treatment'. This creates a multi-tier supply chain where the customer group has limited visibility and control, increasing the risk of disruptions or quality issues originating from sub-suppliers.
risks.impact: Potential for quality defects, capacity constraints, or delays from sub-suppliers that are not directly managed by the customer group. This could impact the final product's quality and availability.
risks.mitigation: Require the supplier to disclose their key sub-suppliers for all outsourced critical processes. The customer group's SQA (Supplier Quality Assurance) team should have the right to audit these sub-suppliers. The supplier must also provide their sub-supplier management and risk mitigation plan.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Contractually require the supplier to identify all Tier-2 suppliers for critical processes.
Action 2: Secure audit rights for the customer group at these Tier-2 supplier facilities.
Action 3: Review and approve the supplier's Tier-2 risk management and contingency plans.

risks.title: Unquoted and Unclear Decarbonization Costs
risks.description: The supplier's proposal explicitly states that 'Potential costs not integrated in this price proposal' for decarbonization solutions. This introduces a significant financial uncertainty, as future sustainability requirements will likely mandate such solutions. This conflicts with the business context of considering 'group-wide sustainability commitments'.
risks.impact: Unforeseen and unbudgeted cost increases during the contract period as sustainability regulations tighten. This could negatively affect the total cost of ownership and profitability of the vehicle platforms.
risks.mitigation: Require the supplier to provide a technology and cost roadmap for decarbonization options (e.g., use of green steel, renewable energy in production). Negotiate and cap potential future costs or agree on a transparent cost-sharing model for implementing these solutions.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Request a formal presentation on the supplier's sustainability roadmap and its potential cost implications.
Action 2: Negotiate a 'cap' or a cost-sharing mechanism for future sustainability-driven changes and include it in the contract.
Action 3: Align the supplier's sustainability targets with the customer group's own commitments.

risks.title: Incomplete Backup Systems and Contingency Plans
risks.description: The supplier confirms that internal backup systems (machines, tools) are only 'Partly' available for critical processes. They refer to an 'emergency preparedness document' for contingency measures, but this document has not been provided for review. This creates a risk of extended downtime in case of equipment failure.
risks.impact: Significant production delays if a non-redundant critical process fails. Inability to meet the 48-hour escalation supply commitment, leading to potential line-down situations at customer plants.
risks.mitigation: Demand immediate submission and joint review of the 'emergency preparedness document'. Identify all critical processes without internal backups and require the supplier to establish and qualify external backup suppliers for these processes. The validation of these contingency plans should be part of the PPAP process.
mitigation_actions: Action 1: Obtain and formally review the supplier's emergency preparedness and contingency plans.
Action 2: Identify critical single points of failure in the production process.
Action 3: Require the supplier to conduct and document a successful trial run of their contingency plan (e.g., activating a backup tool or supplier).
